title: Anoles
description: A scientist searches through jars of pickled anole lizards at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology to find traces of evolution in action.

title: E.O. Wilson and Ants
description: Evolutionary biologist E.O. Wilson has spent his long career cracking the code of ants. It’s the ants’ ability to communicate and form tight-knit societies that lies behind their extraordinary evolutionary success.

title: Arctic Tern
description: Arctic terns travel distances of more than 50,000 miles, from pole to pole, crossing through temperate and tropical regions along the way.

title: Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
description: Learn about the process of tagging tuna and how those tags are revealing surprises that might help save tuna from their own popularity in sushi restaurants.

title: Bacteria
description: In this podcast we raise the blinds on an invisible world that’s all around us: the realm of bacteria.

title: Bees
description: Venture into a cloud of honey bees to learn about the unique way one bee scientist is managing to help bees and fund his research at the same time.

title: Beetles and Moths
description: Tiny stowaways like the European gazelle beetle are arriving on container ships and wreaking havoc with native ecosystems.

title: Bittersweet Nightshade
description: Some species are born invaders, like bittersweet nightshade, a non-native vine. So what makes it such a successful space invader while other foreign plants never make it?

title: Bowhead Whale
description: Journey to Barrow, Alaska to join in the festival of Naluqatak and learn about the intimate relationship between the Inupiat people and the bowhead whale.

title: Box Jellyfish
description: A researcher works to unlock the secrets of the venom of Carybdea alata, beautiful, and sometimes dangerous, angels of the sea.

title: Chaffinch and Wren
description: Learn what two common songsters, the chaffinch and winter wren, are singing about, and how city dwellers can learn to “bird by ear” in their neighborhoods.

title: Chamois
description: A story about one sort of relationship a person can have with an animal - and how that relationship can change.

title: Chinook Salmon
description: Can painted wooden fish on a schoolyard fence change human behavior and help clean up the ocean for real salmon?

title: Coral Reefs
description: Coral reefs are bustling cities of marine life, until rising ocean temperatures turn them into ghost towns. Can reefs spring back from devastating bleaching events?

title: Corpse Flower
description: We visit a sacred island off the coast of Madagascar, where an intrepid botanist braved fever and worse to bring a specimen of this unlikely botanical superstar back alive.

title: De la kar
description: An ethnobotanist hopes that a native tree will help an island nation avoid an epidemic.

title: Dinoflagellates
description: A musical from the bottom of the food chain ... billions of these microscopic luminescent creatures in every bucket of the salty sea.

title: Dolphins
description: A story about tuna, the intertwined fate of fisheries and dolphins, and the work of scientists.

title: Ediacaran Fauna
description: Journey back in time to learn about Ediacaran fauna, a diverse group of organisms that lived in the world's oceans about 580 million years ago.

title: Edicarian Fossils II
description: In Portugal Cove South in southern Newfoundland, there’s a story of two vanished species, and how people had to turn from depending on one to depending on the other.

title: Foothill Yellow Legged Frog
description: We wade into the issue of dams and biodiversity with two biologists sampling the DNA of this threatened frog in order to save it.

title: Four Leaf Clover
description: What if you had the unusual ability to find 4-leaf (and 5,6 even 7-leaf!) clovers?

title: Fungi
description: Learn how this mysterious form of life, neither animal nor vegetable, shapes our world.

title: Giant Squid
description: How do you get two dead giant squid the size of a school bus from a fishing boat in Spain to a museum in Washington, DC, USA?

title: Great White Shark
description: Learn about the great white shark, the charismatic predator at the top of the ocean food chain.

title: Greenland Shark
description: Join shark expert Greg Skomal as he ventures under the Arctic ice in search of the Greenland shark.

title: Biodiversity in the City
description: We’ll join two naturalists on a walk through the heart of Exeter, a city in southwestern England known more for its football club and cathedral than for its wildlife. You may be surprised at what we find.

title: Hungarian Vipers
description: As new ways of farming replace the old, these vipers have been pushed to the brink of extinction. Can conservationists change the hearts and minds of local farmers in time to preserve this critically endangered species?

title: Insects of Costa Rica
description: We travel to Costa Rica to experience firsthand the astonishing variety of insect life in this tiny Central American nation—20,000 different kinds of butterflies and moths alone!

title: Iron-oxidizing Bacteria
description: When you think of life on Earth, plants and animals probably spring to mind. But there are species so odd – so unexpected - that you’d never even dream them up. And yet, they’re often thriving in the most ordinary of places.

title: Island Fox
description: Learn how conservationists solved the puzzle of vanishing island foxes and helped them stage a comeback.

title: Killer Whale
description: Imagine yourself immersed in a chilly, blue, three-dimensional world, one where vision isn’t much use but sound travels far. That’s the leap of the imagination demanded of scientists who study killer whales.

title: Lebanon Cedar
description: Visit the Shouf Cedar Reserve in Lebanon to learn how scientists are working to save the last remaining Lebanon cedar trees from climate change.

title: Lice
description: We talk to an entomologist to learn about an insect that’s the bane of parents and school principals everywhere—or is it?

title: Lichens
description: Lichen are amazing symbiotic organisms, formed when a fungus partners with an algae. Each lichen can host an entire microcosm, a microbial landscape teeming with life.

title: Lions
description: Learn about the diversity of lions in the distant past and the challenges they face in the present.

title: Sea Turtles
description: Cyprus is split in half, with a Turkish sector in the north and a Greek sector in the south. The unofficial division makes scientific collaboration and management of the island's endangered sea turtles a challenge.

title: Mangroves
description: Learn what’s threatening these unique ecosystems where the ocean meets the land.

title: Marabou Stork
description: Marabou storks have wingspans of up to 9 or 10 feet. They’re dark and graceful; but up close is a different matter.

title: Marine Iguana
description: No iguana wants to be cooked alive on a hot rock and then served up as dinner for a Galapagos hawk. But it turns out the marine iguanas have a strategy that warns them of the presence of hawks they can’t see.

title: Martens
description: Determining how changes to the forest are affecting pine and stone martens requires some scientific detective work—and the willingness to gather some rather smelly data.

title: Mexican Long-nosed Bats
description: Join bat researcher Rodrigo Medellin as he descends into the Devil’s Cave just north of Mexico City.

title: Midas Fly
description: A lake accidentally created by waste water from a desalination plant serving the growing city of Al Ain has brought change to the mydas fly that are adapted to life in this stark and beautiful landscape.

title: Monarch Butterflies I
description: Every year monarch butterflies begin a journey north from their overwintering grounds in Mexican forests. In this first of two episodes, we’ll meet Mexican geographer Isabel Ramírez and American biologist Karen Oberhauser who are working to save monarch habitat on both ends of this remarkable insect’s 2,500 mile journey.

title: Monarch Butterflies II
description: It takes up to four generations of butterflies a full year to leave Mexico, flutter north as far as Canada, and then make it back to Mexico. Thousands of citizen scientists and everyday people are helping the butterflies along the way.

title: Montana Spiders
description: Knapweed, cinquefoil, and other weeds aren’t only changing the look of this grassland ecosystem in Montana but its very structure. Some species are benefitting from the changed habitat in unexpected ways.

title: Moths
description: Like moths to a flame, some people are irresistibly drawn to the woods at night. Carrying bed sheets and armed with special lights and lures, they come seeking moths.

title: Muskoxen
description: Introduced to Norway from Greenland in the 1940s, muskoxen flourished on cool, dry slopes until 2006, when the seemingly healthy animals began to die.

title: New species in the Old World
description: You don’t always have to venture into the heart of a rain forest to discover a new species. Sometimes all you have to do is look more closely, right where you are.

title: Parasitic Wasps
description: Sometimes it’s hard to tell where one organism stops and another begins. That’s especially true with the kind of evolutionary race that takes place between parasites and their unwilling hosts.

title: Polar Bear
description: Two amazing polar bear stories from scientists in the field.

title: Prairie dogs
description: Over the past century the grasslands of northern Mexico have been taken over by shrubby mesquite and turned to desert. Can an entire prairie ecosystem be restored with the help of an unlikely ally?

title: Quinine Tree
description: In a large greenhouse at the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis, Missouri, there grows a slender sapling of a tree that has played a remarkable role in human history.

title: Raptors
description: Can the raptors of Beijing stage a comeback, in the face of runaway development? Will the people of Beijing make room for raptors?

title: Ravens
description: Journey to Austria to learn how social learning happens in ravens.

title: Red Knot
description: The red knot is a tiny shorebird that undertakes a mind-boggling migration from the tip of South America all the way to the Arctic Circle.

title: Red Paper Lantern Jellyfish
description: The red paper lantern jelly is teaching researchers in Japan how intricately life is connected down in the ocean’s deep, dark depths.

title: Red Shouldered Soapberry Bug
description: Evolutionary biologists are studying this snazzy red-and-black insect with the big name that are speedy and hard to catch—and speedy in other ways, too.

title: Red Swamp Crawfish
description: In this story, one species takes a journey that is nothing less than a circumnavigation powered by biology, and by business.

title: Vent Worms
description: Meet Riftia, a tube worm that lives in deep-sea vents, and learn the surprising lessons this denizen of the abyss is teaching scientists about life on Earth.

title: Right Whale
description: Playing female whale calls into the water, a researcher suddenly finds herself the center of attention of a group of male North Atlantic right whales.

title: Saltwater Crocodiles
description: The city of Darwin in Australia’s Northern Territory lies in the heart of crocodile country. Can the human citizens learn to live alongside their toothy neighbors?

title: Sanibel Shells
description: Learn why Sanibel Island’s shores are so rich in molluscan treasure, and how shelling has captured the imaginations of scientists and enthusiasts alike.

title: Scottish Wildcat
description: Scottish wildcats have been around since the last ice age. The cats used to roam the whole of Great Britain, but researchers believe there are now fewer than 400 left in the rugged highlands.

title: Sea Butterflies
description: Sea butterflies, or pteropods are an integral part of the marine food web, and they’re in danger because the chemistry of the world’s oceans is changing.

title: Sea Cucumber
description: What reef animal comes in a rainbow of crazy colors, can throw out its innards to immobilize predators, then creep away and regrow a brand-new stomach? It’s the sea cucumber!

title: Sea Grapes
description: “Sea grapes” may sound like something Poseidon would snack on, and not a killer algae. Yet Caulerpa racemosa var. cylindracea poses a serious threat to marine life.

title: Sea Grass
description: Many species thrive in thickets of Posidonia oceanica, a seagrass, which also protects shorelines from erosion, and stores carbon. But it’s not faring so well. It’s slowly disappearing.

title: Sea Slugs
description: Meet Elysia chlorotica, a bright green, solar-powered, algae-slurping sea slug that’s turning our understanding of the classification of life upside down.

title: Springtails
description: Until 2000, biologists classified these curious animals as insects. Then new DNA evidence forced scientists to revise their thinking and redraw a branch on the tree of life.

title: Starlings
description: A story in two acts about a very familiar bird—the common starling.

title: Tulips
description: Tease apart the genetic secrets of the flower whose spectacular genetic variation caused “tulip mania” in the 1600s and has made it a star in the genetics lab in the twenty-first century.

title: Ugandan Butterflies
description: Change can be measured in many ways—in the inches of rainfall, acres of forest cleared—or the span of a tiny butterfly’s wings.

title: Water Hyacinth
description: It may have pretty purple flowers, but Eichhornia crassipes can be a green menace. Introduced to Africa from the neotropics, this invasive weed is choking Lake Victoria, the world’s second largest lake.

title: Western Silvery Aster
description: Tallgrass prairie may seem a world away from our modern lives, but the flora and fauna in this endangered ecosystem are intimately connected with our own well-being.
